comment: The nuance is that in the US there is a difference between Calculus and Analysis courses. Calculus is about calculations, Analysis is more about theorems and proofs. In my country at universities, we have been only taught Analysis courses, which from the beginning start with a lot of hard and abstract theory.

Well in this context he is referring to limits. So yes, your interpretation is correct. He goes over this, but I feel I should mention that this is important for taking derivatives. A tangent line only touches a curve at one point, so, as opposed to a secant line that has two intersections and whose slope can be calculated with those two, a tangent line’s slope cannot be determined in this way. The idea is that if those is two points get closer and closer to the point where the distance between them becomes 0, then that calculated slope would be identical to the slope of the tangent line.  Bottom line. It ‘approaches 0’ in the sense that we calculate values as if the distance is 0. We use the limit notation as simply saying that the distance is 0 causes all sorts of problems that come with dividing by 0.
i want to think i undrestand the general idea behind limits , but something just keeps bugging me , any resource for undrestanding limits another way?
Well thats the definition of limit...

delta y/delta x is simply the gradient between any two points on the function e.g. (x = 10 and x = -12) while dy/dx is the gradient of the tangent line of one specific point. A real life example would be a graph that shows the speed of a car over time. If the car is accelerating and decelerating randomly, delta y/delta x would be the average acceleration between two points, while dy/dx would be the net acceleration at say 1.5 seconds.

He's talking about speed as a vector. Since height is decreasing by 20 metres each second, it makes sense when you need the height to be zero ,you started at 80 m ,you need to get at 0 height. So obviously you need to subtract 20 m . Think of it as an Arithmetic progression ,where in order to get to a smaller number the common difference has to be negative. Or just make a graph of distance versus time.. Since,we know that the tangent of the graph of distance versus time gives us the speed.(tangent or slope tells us the ratio of rise and run along a graph). To get to lesser height ,the y coordinates will shift down but the time x coordinate will keep on increasing and the tangent along that line would be negative because a smaller value- bigger value gives us a negative value. I hope this clears things up

7:04 Gravity's value is 9,8m/s^2, not 10m/s^2. Hence, the equation is h = 80 - 4,9 t^2 (4,9 is half the acceleration - gravity in this case), and not h = 80 - 5 t^2 as shown. How can a MIT teacher say it's 10m/s^2? The formula the student asked for is: y = y(initial) + v(initial)t + 1/2 at^2.  y= position (y at ground level, y(initial) at the top) v= velocity (zero at the top) a= acceleration (gravity in this case) t= time Acceleration assumes a negative value because you're heading down in the y axis. I just took my physics final exam and I feel quite picky about this. 9,8, not 10! I expect 10m/s^2 from bloggers, not from MIT teachers.

I know this is an old comment, and you may have already figured out the answer, but it was a vertical distance equation. The ballistic flight trajectory is a parabola, and d=rt-5t^2 is the equation to find the height from the ground at any point in time during the flight. d = vertical distance, r = rate, t = time. I believe -5t^2 is the distance removed accounting for the deceleration of gravity, but you can look it up to find more information. The formula he used was the same just with h replacing d.
Vertical Motion might be a better way to say it.

And that if someone asks me what is the derivative of some function, would I be answering only an approximation?

Everything when you are doing math makes sense. You're missing something, but it's not your fault, because this course does not start from the very beginning. You should have a deep knowledge of the "limit theory", if you want to really understand what a derivative is. Anyway, I try to explain you what happens here: (x-x0) is not zero before you make the "limit operation". When you apply the "limit operation" to (x-x0), it becomes zero! In fact, you can see it by yourself in the video. In the left there is lim(x->x0) and it means that you don't apply the limit operation yet. But in the right, there is no more the limit notation, so you have applied the limit. And that's why you can write that x-x0 is zero.

But if thats the case, then M&Ding by zero would be illegal. How can we apply x=x0 even in the RHS? My point is that, when talking about limit, the very premise is that x tends to x0(and not that x is equal to x0). But when solving it, all of a sudden x instead of tending to x0, it somehow becomes x0. Like how is it fair that in one case x ONLY tends to x0, but in another it is x0 all of a sudden?  Like if we think x0 = 2, then in LH we are saying that x tends to 2(meaning some value of x could be 1.999 with an epsilon error of 0.001). But in RHS, all of a sudden, he is plugging in the value of x = 2(instead of 1.999). He is essentially throwing that epsilon error (which is the premise of Limit theory) on RHS. Now it would not be a problem, if it is just an approximation(where we are happy with having that epsilon error rate). However if he is saying that there is no error, then this makes no sense which is exactly what my question was.

The problem is that you don't know clearly what a limit is. For instance, let's say that the limit of f(x) as x approach to x0, is L. What does it means? It means "EACH epsilon>0 you take, you can find a real number, let's call it delta, so that |f(x)-L|<delta when |x-x0|<epsilon". Now you can demonstrate that lim of (x-x0) as x approach to x0, is zero, just following my definition of limit. You have to fix an epsilon error, every positive number is good (for example 0.0001). I have to find a delta so that |f(x)-L|=|x-x0-0|<delta when |x-x0|<epsilon. You should see that you can choose delta=epsilon, because it's clearly true that |x-x0|<epsilon when |x-x0|<epsilon. So I found my delta, and I demonstrated that lim(x->x0)x-x0=0. Now it is true that dividing by zero is not allowed by the real number axioms! But the professor is not dividing by zero, but he is applying the limit operation to (f(x)-f(x0))/x-x0, and x is not equal to x0. There is a theorem that says "the limit of the product is the product of the limits",  so that the limit of the right side is equals to the limit of (f(x)-f(x0))/x-x0 multiplied the limit of x-x0. The first limit is by definition the derivative of f and the second one we know that is zero. I don't know if you understand what I'm saying, it's not so easy to me explain complicated topics like this in English :)

I still dont get it. He M&Ds by (x-x0) and says that it is legal because (x-x0) is non-zero(meaning x is not x0). It maybe small, but non-zero. But how is the second term's limit zero then? Shouldn't it be a number closer to zero(but still non-zero)?  What I am saying is that he says x-x0 != 0. Meaning x != x0. So how did we get x-x0 to be zero in second term? If he gets x-x0 to be zero, it means x == x0. But in first statement he uses x!=x0.  I mean we multiplied and divided by a non-zero number(non-zero being the key here). If that's the case, it means that x-x0 is non-zero. Then how can it become zero all of a sudden in the next equation? I understand the definition of limit, but it just seems weird that they are using two definitions when trying to refer to same value which is x-x0. In one case, its not non-zero, but in another it is?   Anyway thanks for your response. I understand English isnt your first language(same like me).

@blasttrash  Yes, intuitively you can think about (x-x0) as a number INFINITELY closer to zero, but not zero! Obviously you can devide for a number that is not zero. It is 0.001? No, It is lower. Maybe 0.00000000000001? No, it is smaller. Smaller than every number, but not zero!  So, in the right side, we have the derivative of the function (that is a finite number) multiplied by that strange number that is smaller than everything, that strange number that is the closest number to zero. But this product is clearly zero, don't you think? The professor needs to give a name for this limit, he calls it zero, because it behaves like a zero. You might think that the differentiation is an approximation and in a certain way you're right, but is the closest approximation to reality, so close that can be confused with the reality itself. Just like lim (x-x0) is the closest thing to zero. Anyway, if you don't like math, in my opinion, it's because no one taught correctly to you. Math is logic, you cannot invent a result because it is convenient. Do not confuse mathematics with religions :)

What a guy; Boss+

45:12  Paraphrasing (and trying to cast it in the best light), here's what I heard:  Given a function whose derivative f'(x) exists at x0, prove that the function is continuous at x0.  1. By definition,  a function f(x) is continuous at the point x0 iff the lim as x->x0 of f(x) is equal to f(x0). 2. Stated equivalently, a function f(x) is continuous at the point x0 iff the [lim as x->xo of f(x)] -  f(x0)  is equal to zero. 3. So Let Z = [the lim as x->x0 of f(x)] - f(x0)  (and we'll see if we can get it to come out zero somehow). 4. Z = [the lim as x->x0 of f(x)]  -  [the lim as x->x0 of f(x0)]. 5. Z = the lim as x->x0 of [f(x) - f(x0)]. 6. Z = the lim as x->x0 of [f(x) - f(x0)] *  { [lim x->x0 of (x-x0)] / [lim x->x0 of (x-x0)] }. 7. Z = the lim as x->x0 of { [f(x) - f(x0)] / [lim x->x0 of (x-x0)] } *  [lim x->x0 of (x-x0)]. 8. Z = the lim as x->x0 of { [f(x) - f(x0)] / (x-x0) } * [lim x->x0 of (x-x0)]. 9. Z = f'(x0) * [lim x->x0 of (x-x0)].  (a critical step.  it removes the divide-by-zero conundrum.) 10. Z = f'(x0) * 0. 11. Z = 0.  Therefore, Given the existence of f'(x0),  which makes step 9 possible, the [lim as x->xo of f(x)] -  f(x0)  is equal to zero, and consequently the given function is continuous.  This is proof by demonstrating that the hypothesis plays an indispensable role in the conclusion.  Not my favorite method (by far!), but in the absence of a review of the algebra of absolute values and in the absence of an introduction of the epsilon-delta definition of a limit, I can't see how else the professor could have done it.  This course will be challenging to me in ways the authors never intended.  :)

I think limits are more important. IF you give students "here is a derivative. I don't know what it is, but just learn it and memorize it." Sure, maybe some of them will pass, but to only the types of questions you teach them. IF you were to teach them limits instead however, they will have a better understanding of a derivative if you teach them the actual definition of a derivative (limit as h approaches zero, etc. etc). It's like teaching a student how do a flip. Teaching them a cartwheel would have them ahve a better grasp on the type of stunt. THEN learning how to flip, the students would have a better understanding on how it should be done.
InternetManiac The cartwheel may be easier to learn after learning the flip as well.

Well in the case of calculus, it's easier to learn derivatives knowing where it really came from.  Just simply saying,  "follow these rules and you'll find the derivative of a function" may leave some students confused, whereas if you learned limits first and taught them the actual equation of a derivative, it'd be a bit more easier. besides, it does not matter too much whether you learn the limits or the derivatives first.. so you might as well learn the limits!

The proof at the end starts off with: f(x) x->a = f(a) - the definition of continuous. So f(x) x->a - f(a)=0.   Then simplifies to f'(a)*0, this however only holds if a function is continuous. If a function was not continuous then it would simplify to f'(a)*some constant. As f(x) x->a - f(a)=c - is not continuous.  Which would make it not = 0.   And in order to be differentiable x-a has to go to zero (by definition). That is how differentiable implies continuous.  I hope this helps.

They would be better served by 2 years at a junior college catching up to their peers.   To make matters worse, these students with inadequate preparation are in this calculus class competing against students with 2 years of calculus study.   The only way it would work is if these same students from very poor areas had access to open course ware and other online resources and the will to do the work without the aid of a paid teacher. Its possible, but the odds become stacked against those students arriving unprepared.

Look, your product rule argument is circular.  The proof of the product rule "assumes" two things:  1) That the limits exist.  2) that the functions are differentiable (at least around the limits).  Continuity can't be proven, if that is the assumption you are beginning with.
You just said something exactly as he stated it.  I know exactly what he did.  My whole point is that the logic of solving each limit independently is flawed.
The whole thing is mathematically un-provable and only rests on the heuristic/intuitive concept of curvilinear continuity.

@yalg22 @yalg22 1) is not the definition of the derivative since it is multiplied by (x-xzero)   Also, independent limit taking is a neat trick.  It really makes no sense intuitively.  That is the whole problem with the proof.  Without independent limit taking you end up with 0/0 in the limit multiplied by some unknown delta f which also approaches zero in the limit under the assuption of continuity.

I don't buy the last proof.  If one never actually uses x = xzero, a zero never exists.  In the limit we don't know if f prime tends to zero, infinity, finite, or undefined.  Therefore, we don't know if the final product ever approaches zero.

In your first equation, the acceleration is divided by 2.  xf = x0 + v* t + a/2 * t²

Do you recognize this as one of the motion equations in the vertical direction?  y = y0 + Vy0*t + (1/2)*a*t^2  y0 = 80 m, the height of the building Vyo = 0 m/s, the pumpkin starts at rest. a = g = -10 m/s^2 y = h,  final pumpkin height  Substitute into your eq h = 80 m + 0 /ms * t + (1/2) (-10 m/s^2) * t^2 h = 80 m -5 m/s^2 * t^2 dh/dt = -10 m/s^2 * t Now at t=4 sec dh/dt = -40 m/s, not 80 m/s as you stated.

Wow,  YOU totally fail!   That is the standard equation for a free fall object, with eighty meters as the height.    Integrate the equation to get Velocity.  V = -10(m/s^2)*t.  Get it? Hi. 's' is used to represent displacement or distance because 'd' already has a job in calculus, as in 'dx' and dt'. Using a 'd' would cause ambiguity. Hence, 's' is not used for speed. Speed is (like velocity) represented by 'v' (the context clarifies the usage). :)
s=displacement is used here, i think this notation is more popular
